root.pub-comments: "The Yuat languages are very poorly known; I only have data on three of them: Biwat, Bun and Miyak. […] We must conclude that these Yuat languages are not related to the Lower Sepik-Ramu language and constitute at least one separate language family (perhaps more?) within the region, the extent of which remains to be determined" (Foley 2005:126).
root.publications: Foley, William A. 2005. Linguistic prehistory in the Sepik-Ramu basin. In Richard Attenborough, Jack Golson, Robert Hide & Andrew K Pawley (eds.), Papuan Pasts: Cultural, Linguistic and Biological Histories of Papuan-Speaking Peoples, 109-144. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858835622

child.pub-comments: "These three are transparently related, with Biwat and Bun possibly being dialects of one language, and Miyak, a clearly distinct, more distantly related language" (Foley 2005:126).
child.publications: Foley, William A. 2005. Linguistic prehistory in the Sepik-Ramu basin. In Richard Attenborough, Jack Golson, Robert Hide & Andrew K Pawley (eds.), Papuan Pasts: Cultural, Linguistic and Biological Histories of Papuan-Speaking Peoples, 109-144. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858835622

root.geography: spoken in the Yuat River region; surrounded on three sides by languages of the extended Lower Sepik-Ramu family
